I'm on a Half-Life playthrough, and this is the 3rd game I've played out of the series so far (Half-Life + Opposing Force). Although the game is short, I loved it. It is more simple than the other games, however that makes it fun. The ending was great, and the short story was good too. It disappointed me that there are no new guns, but I saw right past that.

An official but non-canonical Half Life mini-campaign from Gearbox. Relatively playable, but mediocre level design exposes the (once impressive) quality of the AI - lots of backpedalling and waiting for dim-witted marines to round the corner into your shotgun barrel. Zen levels are worse than Half Life's, and require 15 minutes of crawling through head-crab ridden air shafts into small, featureless chambers. Increased grenade and ammo capacity removes much of the need to strategise - a disappointing deviation from the base game. The scientists are likeable, which is an improvement.

Classic HL expansion. Blue Shift is probably my favourite of the original HL games but it is much shorter than HL and feels shorter than Opposing Forces but is probably the same length. Atop of that the same old bugs still persist today. When loading or quick loading a game it's not uncommon to keep walking / strafing until you press the same direction button once to rectify the problem or even continuously and automatically fire your weapon, without left clicking, wasting your ammunition until you left click at least once.

Puzzles are a little more difficult and well thought out (with exception having to shoot 'damaged' power boxes).

Overall, a fun game.
Yes.
otra muy buena expansion, me gusta como aparece varias veces gordon!
Much shorter than Half-life and Opposing force. Variety of weapons is also very limited compared with these two games. But it's still fun.
yes

Unlike Opposing Force, Blue Shift doesn't really build on the base games mechanics (Half Life 1); there are no new weapons or traversal additions however the story is still excellent and the gameplay remains fresh and exciting. Getting to play as a security guard and explore the security force office adds another level of detail to the world of Half Life and just makes me even more obsessed with this series! Blue Shift might be short but it's still just as fun as the others.

I highly recommend getting the Half Life 1 Anthology Bundle as you will get the main game (Half Life 1), Opposing Force (which is one of the best dlc I have ever played) and Blue Shift.

I can recommend to half life fans, when it is on sale. It was nice, and there were some great moments in this game. There were some really nice areas and puzzles, plus you get to see [spoiler]Gordon Freeman[/spoiler]. Criticism: it is short. I completed it in 2.6 hours, which pales in opposing force's 9 hours. The ending was a bit abrupt and a little underwhelming, I wish it would have some final challenge or something goes wrong or something. Sometimes I felt slightly that I needed to wait until something was complete. There are no special weapons. All in all I enjoyed it.
Play this if you liked half life original

WHAT? You haven't played Half-Life: Blue Shift yet?

Half-Life: Blue Shift is the shortest game in the series and does not have any gameplay changes relative to the original. But here there is a completed plot and it does not break off like a cliffhanger. And also only 1 meeting with G-Man, apparently to him in general, a joke at Barney. Half-Life: Blue Shift may seem the most boring and unnecessary part, but it is very important. It is she who connects the first and second parts. It takes place in one breath in 2 hours, allowing you to enjoy the already outdated but still excellent gameplay of the original. 9/10.

Good Half Life expansion. I like it more than Opposing Force, but it is way shorter.

[b] NO FANFARE FOR THE ORDINARY [/b]

The second spin-off/stand-alone title of Half-Life. A great game, but I‚Äôm with the general consensus: the first title, Opposing Force, is far superior in terms of length, plot and variety of enemies, weapons, physics and combat mechanics.

Blue Shift‚Äôs strength lies on the fact that you‚Äôre not a hero, nobody special, and your mission is just to survive. Plain and simple. No fanfare, no final boss, no special reward, nothing. And that is very well executed; you get to play the commoner, the one lower than even the grunts from Opposing Force.

It was an interesting approach to the franchise, where you build down, not up. The more you play, the less relevant the protagonist in question is.

So again, this is a good title, well worth checking it out. Blue Shift stems from a different time and approach to franchise building. A time that, hopefully, we‚Äôll see a resurgence in the future.
